article.bdy:
Dennis Considen (d.1815), surgeon, was born in Ireland. He sailed with the First Fleet as surgeon on the
Scarborough
which transported
English
convicts to
Port Jackson
,
Australia . Considen is best known for his pioneering role in the use of Australian native plants for pharmaceutical use, especially eucalyptus oil, which he used to treat the convicts.1
Pioneering Australian Pharmaceutical Research
Considen used indigenous Australian plants to alleviate a range of diseases which scourged the convict settlement, including scurvy and dysentry. Pharmaceutical preparations included kino from Eucalyptus and Angophora, 'yellow gum' resin from Xanthorrhoea spp., native sarsaparilla Smilax glyciphylla and the 'large peppermint-tree' Eucalyptus piperita.
In November 1788 Considen proclaimed himself to English colleague, Dr Anthony Hamilton, as the colony's pharmaceutic pioneer: "...if there is any merit in applying these & many other simples[sic] to the benefit of the poor wretches here, I certainly claim it, being the first who discovered & recommended them.".2 This claim has contemporary support, although
John White
, Surgeon General to the Colony, is also credited with the discovery, in documenting the matter3 and organizing oil samples to be sent back to England.4
Australian botanist,
Joseph Maiden , expressed the opinion that Considen deserves credit for being the first person to recognize the medicinal value of eucalyptus oil extracted from E. piperita found growing on the shores of
Port Jackson
.5 For further evaluation, Considen also dispatched a Eucalyptus oil sample, on the return voyage to
England on the
Golden Grove
. 6 7
Return to Ireland
In November 1791, after a period on
Norfolk Island working with
D'Arcy Wentworth , Considen returned to Sydney. Considen was granted leave because of ill health, and sailed on the Kitty and arrived at
Cork in February 1794. He served as a hospital mate in the Army Medical Service until he was appointed deputy-purveyor for service on the Continent. In August 1799 he was promoted purveyor which enabled him to study medicine at the
University of Edinburgh , and to support his family.
Considen graduated doctor of medicine on the 24th June, 1804, with a thesis entitled De Tetano in which he refers to his discovery of eucalyptus oil. He was called to Cork to join an expedition bound for the Cape.
Considen maintained an interest in New South Wales and its natural history. He maintained contact with his friends Thomas Arndell,
George Johnston
and D'Arcy Wentworth. Considen's character indicates that he was a humane man with an earnest desire to do well in his profession. On 6 January 1812 he was admitted a licentiate of the College of Physicians. He died in 1815.
Joseph Maiden dedicated Eucalyptus consideniana in recognition of his pioneer work with eucalyptus oil.

Eucalyptus piperita

Scarborough
